rule.description: Logging should not be vulnerable to injection attacks
rule.name: pythonsecurity:S5145
rule.full_description: Logging should not be vulnerable to injection attacks
rule.help:
Why is this an issue?

Log injection occurs when an application fails to sanitize untrusted data used for logging.

An attacker can forge log content to prevent an organization from being able to trace back malicious activities.

What is the potential impact?

If an attacker can insert arbitrary data into a log file, the integrity of the chain of events being recorded can be compromised.
This frequently occurs because attackers can inject the log entry separator of the logger framework, commonly newlines, and thus insert artificial log entries.
Other attacks could also occur requiring only field pollution, such as cross-site scripting (XSS) or code injection (for example, Log4Shell) if the logged data is fed to other application components, which may interpret the injected data differently.

The focus of this rule is newline character replacement.

Log Forge

An attacker, able to create independent log entries by injecting log entry separators, inserts bogus data into a log file to conceal his malicious activities. This obscures the content for an incident response team to trace the origin of the breach as the indicators of compromise (IoCs) lead to fake application events.

How to fix it in Flask

Code examples

The following code is vulnerable to log injection as it constructs log entries using untrusted data. An attacker can leverage this to manipulate the chain of events being recorded.

Noncompliant code example

import logging

app = Flask(__name__)

@app.route('/example')
def log():
    data = request.args["data"]
    app.logger.critical("%s", data) # Noncompliant

Compliant solution

import logging
import base64

app = Flask(__name__)

@app.route('/example')
def log():
    data = request.args["data"]
    if data.isalnum():
        app.logger.critical("%s", data)
    else:
        app.logger.critical("Invalid Input: %s", base64.b64encode(data.encode('UTF-8')))

How does this work?

Data used for logging should be content-restricted and typed. This can be done by validating the data content or sanitizing it.
Validation and sanitization mainly revolve around preventing carriage return (CR) and line feed (LF) characters. However, further actions could be required based on the application context and the logged data usage.

Here, the example compliant code uses the isalnum function to ensure the untrusted data is safe. If not, it performs Base64 encoding to protect from log injection.

Resources

Standards

  • OWASP Top 10 2021 Category A3 - Injection
  • OWASP Top 10 2021 Category A9 - Security Logging and Monitoring Failures
  • OWASP Top 10 2017 Category A1 - Injection
  • OWASP Top 10 2017 Category A10 - Insufficient Logging & Monitoring
  • MITRE, CWE-20 - Improper Input Validation
  • MITRE, CWE-117 - Improper Output Neutralization for Logs

message.text:
Change this code to not log user-controlled data.

See more on SonarCloud

author: pdteam

info.description:
TLS version detection is a security process used to determine the version of the Transport Layer Security (TLS) protocol used by a computer or server.
It is important to detect the TLS version in order to ensure secure communication between two computers or servers.

rule.name: js/xss-through-dom
rule.full_description: Reinterpreting text from the DOM as HTML can lead to a cross-site scripting vulnerability.

message.text: DOM text is reinterpreted as HTML without escaping meta-characters.

technologies.name: Python
technologies.description: Python is an interpreted and general-purpose programming language.

technologies.name: Django
technologies.description: Django is a Python-based free and open-source web application framework.

technologies.name: Bootstrap
technologies.description: Bootstrap is a free and open-source CSS framework directed at responsive, mobile-first front-end web development. It contains CSS and JavaScript-based design templates for typography, forms, buttons, navigation, and other interface components.

technologies.name: React
technologies.description: React is an open-source JavaScript library for building user interfaces or UI components.

technologies.name: styled-components
technologies.description: Styled components is a CSS-in-JS styling framework that uses tagged template literals in JavaScript.

technologies.name: Google Ads
technologies.description: Google Ads is an online advertising platform developed by Google.

technologies.name: Google Analytics
technologies.description: Google Analytics is a free web analytics service that tracks and reports website traffic.

technologies.name: Google Ads Conversion Tracking
technologies.description: Google Ads Conversion Tracking is a free tool that shows you what happens after a customer interacts with your ads.

technologies.name: Matomo Analytics
technologies.description: Matomo Analytics is a free and open-source web analytics application, that runs on a PHP/MySQL web-server.

technologies.name: jQuery
technologies.description: jQuery is a JavaScript library which is a free, open-source software designed to simplify HTML DOM tree traversal and manipulation, as well as event handling, CSS animation, and Ajax.

technologies.name: jsDelivr
technologies.description: JSDelivr is a free public CDN for open-source projects. It can serve web files directly from the npm registry and GitHub repositories without any configuration.

technologies.name: Bootstrap Icons
technologies.description: Bootstrap Icons is a growing library of SVG icons that are designed by @mdo and maintained by the Bootstrap Team.

technologies.name: HSTS
technologies.description: HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) informs browsers that the site should only be accessed using HTTPS.

technologies.name: PWA
technologies.description: Progressive Web Apps (PWAs) are web apps built and enhanced with modern APIs to deliver enhanced capabilities, reliability, and installability while reaching anyone, anywhere, on any device, all with a single codebase.

info.name: SPF Record - Detection
author: rxerium
info.description: An SPF TXT record was detected

info.name: DNS TXT Record Detected
author: pdteam
info.description: A DNS TXT record was detected. The TXT record lets a domain admin leave notes on a DNS server.

info.name: MX Record Detection
author: pdteam
info.description: An MX record was detected. MX records direct emails to a mail exchange server.

info.name: DNS DMARC - Detect
author: juliosmelo
info.description: DNS DMARC information was detected.

info.name: CAA Record
author: pdteam
info.description: A CAA record was discovered. A CAA record is used to specify which certificate authorities (CAs) are allowed to issue certificates for a domain.

info.name: NS Record Detection
author: pdteam
info.description: An NS record was detected. An NS record delegates a subdomain to a set of name servers.

info.name: Cookies without HttpOnly attribute - Detect
author: princechaddha
mr.bobo hp
info.description: Checks whether cookies in the HTTP response contain the HttpOnly attribute. If the HttpOnly flag is set, it means that the cookie is HTTP-only
info.impact: Lack of HttpOnly flag on cookies increases the risk of client-side attacks, compromising user session security and data privacy.
info.remediation: Ensure that all cookies are set with the HttpOnly attribute to prevent client-side access.

info.name: Cookies without Secure attribute - Detect
author: vthiery
info.description: Checks whether cookies in the HTTP response contain the Secure attribute. If the Secure flag is set, it means that the cookie can only be transmitted over HTTPS
info.impact: Lack of Secure flag on cookies allows the cookie to be sent over unsecure HTTP, making it vulnerable to man-in-the-middle (MITM) attacks.
info.remediation: Ensure that all cookies are set with the Secure attribute to prevent MITM attacks.

author: lingtren
info.description: Extract the issuer's organization from the target's certificate. Issuers are entities which sign and distribute certificates.

author: pdteam
info.description: Extract the Subject Alternative Name (SAN) from the target's certificate. SAN facilitates the usage of additional hostnames with the same certificate.
